A Special Purpose Framework (SPF) is used when financial statements are designed to serve specific users or objectives, not everyone. Think of it as the tailor-made suit of financial reporting 👔 — made to measure, not off-the-rack. Common examples include: -Cash basis accounts (common in NGOs) -Regulatory frameworks (SEBI, IRDAI, RBI, etc.) -Contractual reporting (for lenders, donors, or investors) ⚙️ Auditing Under SPF = SA 800 in Action! Yes, these audits are governed by SA 800 – “Special Considerations—Audits of Financial Statements Prepared in Accordance with Special Purpose Frameworks.” Here’s what sets them apart 👇 ✅ Auditor’s opinion must refer explicitly to the framework (e.g., “as described in Note X…”) ✅ Report should state the intended users and purpose clearly ✅ May include a restriction on use or distribution ✅ The framework’s acceptability and disclosure are key 🤔 Here’s the Real Catch! Many finance professionals are still unaware of how the use of SPF audits differ from general-purpose audits — yet these are becoming increasingly common in practice.From lender-specific certifications to donor-driven reports, SPFs are quietly becoming a part of everyday assurance work.
